newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: VIASA shareholders postpone bankruptcy decision.
newsitem.headline: VIASA shareholders postpone bankruptcy decision.

text.p: Shareholders in the grounded Venezuelan airline company VIASA on Saturday postponed a meeting to decide whether or not to seek bankruptcy, according to a statement by a leading shareholder.
Majority shareholders Fondo de Inversiones de Venezuela (FIV) and Spain's Iberia asked VIASA chief executive Jose Campins to call another meeting within the next 12 days.
FIV said it wanted to allow time for a rescue plan, launched on January 28 in Madrid, to proceed.

According to the refinancing plan, Iberia would finance VIASA's debt while FIV would invest $25 million in the enterprise. But the rescue plan also involves 300 job cuts and has yet to be approved by VIASA employees.

William Bracho, a VIASA workers' representative, told Reuters the FIV expects to present its plans to the workers at a meeting on Friday. He said it was important to get the airline back off the ground within 30 days because, if it did not, the airline would have to apply for a new licence to fly to the United States.
The airline suspended all flights on January 23 after workers rejected a previous cost-cutting proposal by Iberia that included 440 job losses, a wage freeze and dropping unprofitable routes.
If the latest proposal is approved, the FIV has said Iberia will probably retire from managing the airline. It is also looking for a new investor willing to run and recapitalise the company.
